thread.title: Pulaski Academy junior gets points across in final
thread.title_full: Pulaski Academy junior gets points across in final

title: Pulaski Academy junior gets points across in final
text:
Pulaski Academy junior gets points across in final By Tim Cooper Posted: October 21, 2015 at 2:40 a.m. Hunter Harrison 
Hunter Harrison did not hit every big shot in Tuesday's Class 5A boys singles championship match, but the Pulaski Academy junior had more than enough to claim a second consecutive title. 
Harrison defeated a game Stuart Riser of Little Rock Christian 6-2, 6-3, at Rebsamen Tennis Center in Little Rock in a match that lasted 85 minutes. 
"The score really didn't reflect the match," Harrison said. "I just think that when it came down to the last point in a lot of the games, I was able to come out with the winner. I was very confident of winning the points I had to win." 
Pulaski Academy swept the singles and doubles titles and rolled to the team title, earning 19 points. Hot Springs Lakeside was a distant second with six points. 
Freshman Wesley Barnett and sophomore Jake Bridges had an easy time winning the doubles title. The Bruins team won all four of their tournament matches 6-0, 6-0, including Tuesday's championship match against junior teammates Robert Cain and Jack Meghreblian. 
Pulaski Academy's girls team shared the state title with Hot Springs Lakeside -- with each team scoring 13 points. The team of Abby Minton and Katie Swanson outlasted the sisters Bailey and Morgan McAlexander of Valley View in the doubles championship match, 6-4, 7-6. 
Another pair of sisters -- Tatum and Thea Rice of Lakeside -- played for the singles title. Tatum won 6-1, 6-4, in a match that was more of a practice session than a serious contest. 
"Next week if we play for the Overall title, then we'll both take it a little more seriously," Tatum Rice said. "We'll be playing hard against each other." 
The boys' singles finalists, meanwhile, provided a wholehearted effort that meant a series of long rallies and hotly contested points. 
Riser, a senior, won the first two games of Tuesday's match, but Harrison said he felt the momentum swing when he broke Riser's serve to tie the match at 2-2. 
"I was really tight and a little nervous even though I've been there before, but I started playing a lot better," Harrison said. "I started ripping my forehands and my backhands and things just started going my way." 
Harrison won nine consecutive games before Riser held serve midway through the second set. Harrison's long winning streak included a between-the-legs return shot that sailed cross court for a game-winner. 
"Let's just say that was the best shot of my life," Harrison said. "I'm not lying. ... It was a winner, and if you saw me I was laughing about it because I knew it was the best shot of my life." 
Riser managed to hold serve three times in second set and saved four match points before Harrison earned the victory. 
All of Tuesday's finalists have qualified for next week's Overall tournament, which will be played at Burns Park Tennis Complex in North Little Rock. 
Sports on 10/21/2015
